conclusion: Determine if the distance fallen from 10 to 15 seconds is greater or less than 75 meters by analyzing the area under the velocity-time graph.
The graph shows velocity as a function of time. From 0 to 10 seconds, velocity increases to about 20 m/s. From 10 to 15 seconds, velocity decreases and stabilizes around 10 m/s.
Distance traveled is given by the area under the velocity-time graph for the interval.
Calculate the area under the curve from 10 to 15 seconds.
The shape of the curve between 10 and 15 seconds is roughly a trapezoid.
The height of the trapezoid is 5 seconds.
The velocities at 10 seconds and 15 seconds are approximately 20 m/s and 10 m/s, respectively.
Calculate the area of the trapezoid using the formula: A = 1/2 * (Base1 + Base2) * Height.
Substitute the values into the formula: A = 1/2 * (20 + 10) * 5 = 75 meters.
The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is exactly 75 meters.
